children.subject: I think you should take (core) SWE classes either way, regardless of whether you want to go down a industry-oriented SWE path. Those classes provide serviceable skills and allow you the security to cash in a mean check in case things don't pan out with your pipe dream (be it ML or AI or robotics or grad school or academia or a startup or something else). Just my opinion, but of course simply taking those courses might not be enough to land a job (since you may need to do other things like personal projects and prep for interviews etc.)

history.content:
Robotics is hard to get into without grad school, but it's possible. A masters is usually recommended, but I've seen people succeed with a BS. If you want to do it with a BS, I would definitely recommend software engineering classes, since unless you have a PhD (or are very lucky) you'll be designing software/firmware/hardware for robots, rather than doing the higher-level research-y stuff.

Regarding 106A/B, a lot of people come into 106A to test the water and get some basic experience with robotics. It's great for that, and will likely give you enough experience to do software engineering for a robotics company (assuming you're already qualified as a software engineer). 106B is significantly harder/more time consuming than 106A, as well as being more research-based, so a good portion of students don't want to take it. That being said, it's a great experience and we're looking at ways to improve the pipeline.

Also a brief anecdote on struggling in classes: I did pretty badly at school my first two years. Out of 20 or so classes I only got 2-3 A's or A-'s, and I got some sort of C in half my core courses. But then the next year I got a bit more used to the rigor of Berkeley, and started taking more project classes (like 106A/B). Seeing the applications gave me the intuition I needed to do better in my theory classes too, and I ended up doing well enough my last two years to get into grad school. Don't give up on your dreams because the first two years are hard.

I'm thinking of taking 106A/B but I've heard you usually need a PhD to be successful in robotics. I'm taking 16B, 170 and 126 and I'm struggling. I would rather spend time taking software engineering classes if that's going to end up being more practical. I've also noticed most people who take 106A don't go on to 106B.
history.subject: Is robotics a smart path?
